questions.text: Which structures are left intact during radical neck dissection?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: B

  • Sublingual gland: The sublingual gland is not removed in a radical neck dissection. Radical neck dissection is a surgical procedure performed to remove lymph nodes and other structures in the neck to treat head and neck cancers. The sublingual gland is located beneath the tongue and is not typically involved in lymph node metastasis or directly affected by head and neck cancers. Therefore, it is preserved during the surgical procedure.

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid gland, which is the largest salivary gland located in the cheek, can be removed in certain cases of radical neck dissection if it is involved by tumour or affected by lymph node metastasis.

Option C. Submandibular gland: The submandibular gland, another salivary gland located beneath the lower jaw, may be removed in specific cases of radical neck dissection if it is involved by tumour or affected by lymph node metastasis.

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: Level 2b lymph nodes are typically included in a radical neck dissection. These lymph nodes are in the upper neck region, near the angle of the mandible. They are commonly removed to ensure adequate clearance of lymphatic tissue in cases of head and neck cancer.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents with a 2-year history of progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and unsteadiness. An MRI scan reveals a well-defined tumor located in the cerebellopontine angle (CPA). A surgical resection is performed, and subsequent histopathological examination of the tumor tissue is given below.



Based on these histopathological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. - Schwannoma:

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical features and the histopathological findings, the most likely diagnosis is Schwannoma (also known as vestibular schwannoma/ acoustic neuroma).
  • The patient presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and unsteadiness, which strongly suggest involvement of vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). MRI shows a CPA (cerebellopontine angle) mass, which is the most common location for vestibular schwannomas.

Histopathology typically shows:

  • Antoni A areas: densely packed spindle cells arranged in palisades (Verocay bodies).
  • Antoni B areas: loosely arranged cells in a myxoid background.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ependymomas are tumors arising from the ependymal lining of the ventricles or central canal of the spinal cord. They do not present in the CPA and are more commonly intraventricular or intraspinal. Histology shows perivascular pseudorosettes, not Antoni patterns.

Option C - Meningiomas can occur in the CPA but are extra-axial, dural-based tumors. On histology, they show whorled patterns, psammoma bodies, and syncytial cells, not Antoni A/B areas.

Option D - Neurofibromas also arise from Schwann cells but are non-encapsulated, infiltrative tumors involving multiple nerve fascicles. Histology lacks Verocay bodies and the distinct Antoni A/B areas. They are more diffuse than the well-circumscribed schwannoma.
